data.meta_description: Climate change is happening and it’s happening faster than previously anticipated. This is especially alarming for Gulf countries, Saudi Arabia and the other…
data.text:
Climate Change Impact on Saudi Arabia Climate change is already having devastating effects in Saudi Arabia. Below are a brief summary of some points: • Climate : significant temperature increases by 2050, ranging from 1.6°C on a low carbon pathway to a concerning 2.6°C on a high carbon pathway. • Sea : predictions of a 1.6°C increase by 2050 under a high-emission scenario. This warming could severely damage marine ecosystems, increase ocean acidification and reduce fish populations by up to 30%. • Costal : Rising sea levels, erosion, and storms due to climate change could put 210,000 people at risk of flooding by 2050. • Economy: The report predicts a potential loss of 12.2% of GDP by 2050 if no action is taken. #sustainability #environment #climatechange #saudiarabia #ksa #ClimateAction #future #economy #GDP #climaterisk

For some bizarre reason we think we can negotiate with the physics that has been set in motion by our continued burning of fossil fuels. The simple truth is we cannot. Take a look at these three examples from the past few weeks. Margate, South Africa: An extreme precipitation event saw 250mm fall in 24hrs. Take a look at the path of devastation from the ensuing flash flood https://lnkd.in/dH2KJz7e Russia’s Kurgan and Tyumen regions and swaths of northern Kazakhstan: Extreme heat rapidly melts snow and ice causing a sea of water to force 100’s of thousands of people to abandon their homes. Take a look https://lnkd.in/d3X6Exsx Gulf States: An extreme weather system moved over Oman and the UEA. Here are images from Dubai after receiving 259mm in a day. https://lnkd.in/d7YFg5vx Here is the IPCC’s comments regarding extreme precipitation events: “Precipitation events – including those associated with tropical cyclones (TCs) – increase with GSAT[Global Surface Air Temperature]. For GWLs [Global Warming Levels]_[ >2°C very rare (e.g., 1-in-10 or more years) heavy precipitation events more frequent and more intense over all continents (virtually certain) and nearly all AR6 regions (likely). Likelihood lower at lower GWLs and for less-rare events. At the global scale, intensification of heavy precipitation generally follows Clausius–Clapeyron (about 6–7% per °C of GSAT warming; high confidence). Increase in frequency of heavy precipitation events accelerates with warming, higher for rarer events (high confidence), with approximately a doubling and tripling frequency of 10-year and 50-year events, respectively, at 4°C of global warming.” Our infrastructure is not designed for this new reality. We urgently need to understand the impacts of a world rapidly approaching 1.5°C of warming. Do you know what to expect in your area as we continue to heat? #climateliteracy #climatecrisis #adaptation
